yield.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to produce a result, answer, or piece of information
yield.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Our research has only recently begun to yield important results.
yield.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Each of these oilfields could yield billions of barrels of oil.
The tourist industry yielded an estimated $2.25 billion for the state last year.
These investments should yield a reasonable return.
yield.translation[0].definitions[1].note: In everyday English, people usually say that something produces a result, a profit etc rather than yields it:
Each cow produces almost 20 litres of milk a day.
yield.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to allow yourself to be forced or persuaded to do something or stop having something
yield.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The military has promised to yield power.
Further action may be necessary if the leaders do not yield to diplomatic pressure.
Finally she yielded to temptation and helped herself to a large slice of cake.
The hijackers refuse to yield to demands to release the passengers.
yield.translation[0].definitions[2].note: In everyday English, people usually say someone gives in to pressures, demands etc rather than yields to them:
I very much doubt the boss will give in to her demands.
yield.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to allow other traffic on a bigger road to go first
yield.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Yield to traffic on the left.
yield.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to move, bend, or break because of physical force or pressure
yield.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Ideally, the surface should yield slightly under pressure.
yield.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to stop fighting and accept defeat
yield.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the amount of profits, crops etc that something produces
yield.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The average milk yield per cow has doubled.
Shareholders are expecting a higher yield this year.
a yield of over six percent
yield.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money that you get from an investment, especially bonds
yield.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Many investors are buying stocks because of low yields in other securities.
yield.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: the amount of something that is produced, such as crops
yield.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Farmers who practise intensive farming are aiming for maximum yields for minimum cost.
yield.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the average amount of money that an AIRLINE gets from each of its passengers for each mile that they fly or by a hotel from each of its guests for each night they stay
yield.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The airlineâ€™s passenger revenue yield rose from 12.8 cents to 12.95 cents.
Officials have said their pricing strategy, known as yield management, is merely a sophisticated approach to supply and demand.
yield.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Mining shares often yield a high level of return.
yield.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to produce a product, crop etc
yield.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: These rice fields now yield 145,000 tons a year.
yield.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to produce a result, answer, or a piece of information
yield.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: The discussions failed to yield any useful results.
Writing to the agents yielded no reply.
